Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Automatic Extraction of Financial Data from Text
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will result from the availability of relevant financial information in structured computer-usable format with high accuracy in near real time. Currently, data embedded in financial text are extracted manually by hundreds of people working for data warehouses. This manual effort takes on the order of weeks making the bulk of the data unavailable in easily computer-usable form in real time. The benefits of this project will be focused in three areas: (i) algorithmic trading programs will be able to use all data published worldwide immediately after the data is published; (ii) financial data warehouses will be able to provide an order of magnitude larger set of data concepts (from < 200 to > 3000); (iii) there will be increased transparency in the financial markets as financial information embedded in text becomes computer-readable. In 2012 algorithmic trading was estimated to exceed $5 Trillion in value with 750 Billion shares traded, generating a profit of over $600 Million. Financial transparency is an intangible benefit that will improve financial market efficiency.

This Small Business Innovative Research (SBIR) Phase II project will develop automated methods to extract and tag relevant financial concepts from the free text of financial documents such as an annual reports, press releases and analyst reports. The extracted financial concepts will be semantically mapped (tagged) to a financial taxonomy such as the US-GAAP or IFRS for standardized analysis. There is a growing need in current financial markets for accurate and timely access to relevant financial information for supporting trading and analysis decisions. At the end of this project, the company's technology is expected to have the capability to provide such information to analysts and decision makers in a timely fashion. The primary goals of this project will be to: (i) build an end-to-end prototype system for automatically extracting financial data from text; (ii) extend the scope of the technology to reach a broader range of real-world applications; (iii) increase accuracy; (iv) reduce the processing time for financial data extraction. The technology will employ machine learning and natural language processing techniques toward financial concept annotation, extraction and semantic tagging to achieve these goals.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

This document is the project outcomes report for BCL Technologies (BCL) for the National Science Foundation Phase II SBIR titled “Automatic Extraction of Financial Data from Text (AEFDT)”.

The abstract of the Phase II work is given below:

The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is the availability of relevant financial information in structured computer-usable format with high accuracy in near real time. Currently, data embedded in financial text are extracted manually by hundreds of people working for data warehouses. This manual effort takes on the order of weeks, making the bulk of the data unavailable in easily computer-usable forms in real time. The benefit of “Automatic Extraction of Financial Data from Text” (AEFDT) will be in three areas: 1) Algorithmic Trading programs will be able to use all data published worldwide immediately after the data is published; 2) Financial data warehouses will be able to provide an order of magnitude larger data concepts (from <200 to >3000); 3) There will be increased transparency in the financial market as financial information embedded in the text becomes computer-readable. Algorithmic trading was estimated to reach over $5 Trillion with 750 Billion shares traded, generating a profit of over $600 Million in 2012. The impact of financial transparency is an intangible benefit that will improve financial market efficiency.

This Small Business Innovative Research (SBIR) Phase II project will develop automated methods to extract and tag relevant financial concepts from the free text of financial documents such as an annual report, a press release or an analyst report. The extracted financial concepts will be semantically mapped (tagged) to a financial taxonomy such as the US-GAAP or IFRS for standardized analysis. There is a growing need in current financial market for accurate and timely access to relevant financial information for supporting trading and analysis decisions. At the end of our Phase II research, BCL’s AEFDT system will have the capability to provide such information to the analysts and decision makers in a timely fashion. The primary goals of this Phase II project will be to: 1) Build end-to-end AEFDT prototype system; 2) Extend the Phase I research to a broader domain for real world applications; 3) Increase accuracy; 4) Reduce the processing time. We will employ machine learning and Natural Language Processing based techniques toward financial concept annotation, extraction and semantic tagging to achieve these Phase II goals.

Outcomes

BCL completed its Phase II work. BCL has: 1) Published a number of papers based on this research; 2) Incorporated the AEFDT technology in its existing products to enhance sales; 3) Developed a new product line based on the AEFDT.

Papers Published

BCL has published the following papers based on this SBIR research:

  1. Experiments in Candidate Phrase Selection for Financial Named Entity Extraction - A Demo. Hassan Alam, Aman Kumar, Tina Werner and Manan Vyas. COLING 2016. Osaka, Japan.
  2. Concept Extraction from a Modifier-Head Pair in the Financial Data. Hassan Alam, Aman Kumar, Kendall Agbulos, Tina Werner, Manan Vyas, Kavya Ravi, Rachmat Hartono. The 15th International Conference on Information & Knowledge Engineering (IKE 2016). Las Vegas.
  3. Financial Data Extraction – An Application. Alam, Hassan, Aman Kumar, Cheryl Lee, Rahul Kumar, David Ju. The Intelligent Systems and Agents 2014 Conference. Multi Conference on Computer Science and Information Systems (MCCSIS). Lisbon, Portugal. July 2014.
  4. Financial Data Tagging and Extraction - A Machine Learning Approach. Alam, Hassan, Aman Kumar, Cheryl Lee, Rahul Kumar, David Ju. The 2014 International Conference on Advances in Big Data Analytics. World Congress in Computer Science Computer Engineering and Applied Computing. Las Vegas, USA. July 21-24, 2014.

Enhance Existing Products

BCL sells financial data extraction products to its customers. The SBIR’s ability to locate financial concepts in text and match them with values (financial data) and time (date) has been used in the following products:

SEC Publisher: A product to convert Word documents to SEC-compliant HTML for submission to the SEC.

SmartXBRL: A product to automatically extract and tag all financial data in public company 10-Q (quarterly filings), 10-K (annual filings) and 8-K (press releases).

Custom products: A number of BCL’s larger financial customers have requested financial data extraction software. BCL has incorporated the SBIR research into these products.

Build New Products

BCL is developing an Earnings Release System (ERS) based on the Phase II research. The ERS (Figure 1) takes the output from the SBIR software (AEFDT) and delivers it to customers in a specific format (Spreadsheet, XML, SQL). The new module being developed by BCL is Post Phase II Commercial Software.

 


Last Modified: 07/23/2017
Modified by: Hassan Alam
